@jamesdgreig It's a stat I've tweeted many times but it bears repeating because it's so striking - UK govt clamped down on heroin prescribing in response to doubling in number of people addicted to opioids during 60s, from 1000 to 2000. The number is now estimated at 342,000

@jamesdgreig Agree that the debate is very sterile here vs US. And if anything we're moving in wrong direction

Interestingly, same dynamic happened before. In late 60s/early 70s, as we phased out prescribing heroin, US doctors were praising "British system" as having contained addiction

@jamesdgreig Safe supply differs from OST, idea is safe supply of every drug should be available to any user, not just oral opioids as part of treatment program. "Drug User Liberation Front" hands out tested packs of heroin, cocaine & meth in Vancouver - illegal but seemingly tolerated

@jamesdgreig Don't think you needed to delete your tweet btw, I think it is interesting how despite history opinion seems to be moving in opposite directions in each country. Canada also interesting case - "safe supply," although still a minority position, is now part of the debate there

@jamesdgreig Even needle exchange, one of the most basic & important harm reduction measures, is still illegal in about 15 states, although some of those allow unofficial programs to operate without interference (kind of like Glasgow police's attitude to Peter Krykant's safe consumption van)

@jamesdgreig ... a special license to prescribe methadone, they're also tightly monitored by FDA so often afraid of taking on too many patients. Whereas in UK any doctor can prescribe methadone, special licenses are only required for prescribing heroin or cocaine to treat addiction

@jamesdgreig Yes and tbf it varies widely by region. More progressive states have been handing out naloxone to users, or even making it freely available in public spaces, like we do with defibrillators, for longer than us. But prescribing is controlled at federal level, and doctors need...

@jamesdgreig Naloxone isn't even controlled drug afaik (it has zero "abuse potential" because it has precisely the opposite effect to heroin, so a regular user who took it would go into withdrawal). Its only use is reversing overdoses. But some states consider it "drug paraphernalia"

@jamesdgreig UK is odd mix because since 70s we've gone all in on the drug war, but public health approach has always been harm reduction since drug control first introduced. In US public health has often been drowned out by criminalization - some states arrest people for carrying naloxone

@CliveBarker1967 ... particular statue. I'm just saying that statues are choices about what cultural & political values we choose to define ourselves. Putting up statues of kings and military leaders is a choice to emphasize the militaristic aspects of our past. That wouldn't be my choice

@CliveBarker1967 .. as subscribing to a culture of masculinity that valorized interpersonal violence, the ability and willingness to kill, as a crucial component of honor. This is what understanding people in their contexts means. As for statues, again I'm not advocating the removal of any...

@CliveBarker1967 I'm not expecting anyone to live up to anything. I'm just expecting honest appraisal of what historical figures did. In the case of Churchill, this means describing him as a committed imperialist and white supremacist. In the case of medieval knights, this means describing them..

@CliveBarker1967 For most of history people did not assume that people who lived in the same city or country should all share the same ethnicity or culture. It was largely an invention of the late 19C and it's responsible for a big share of the violence since then

@CliveBarker1967 Again, nationalism can mean different things. It needn't contain an ethnic component - an anti-colonial struggle, or a celebration of cultural achievements, can be called nationalist. But ethno-nationalist politics has overall been a poisonous force in modern history
@CliveBarker1967 *not sure why anti-aging is in the tweet before last, must be an autocorrect

@CliveBarker1967 ... which not only consisted of colonized peoples fighting back, but also opponents of imperialism within the European core, which included both socialist and conservative movements. Churchill was firmly and consistently on the imperialist side of that contest

@CliveBarker1967 .. the injustice of applying rules retroactively, we're just anti-aging analyzing the impact people had on the course of history. Also, Churchill's historical context was was a struggle between European imperialism, justified by white supremacism, and anti-colonial movements...

@CliveBarker1967 I don't really understand this objection. Of course we try to understand historical figures in their historical context. That doesn't mean we can't make value judgments. People confuse historical analysis with criminal law. Churchill isn't on trial, we don't need to worry about..

@CliveBarker1967 This doesn't mean I think every Churchill statue should come down tomorrow. I just think we need to have honest, non-defensive conversations about what historical figures mean and what political agendas and ideas their commemoration serves

@CliveBarker1967 Otoh I can totally understand why, in the aftermath of the trauma of WW2, many people who weren't racist or imperialist wanted to commemorate Churchill as representing British victory and the defeat of Nazism. But with greater distance, the meaning of the commemoration changes

@CliveBarker1967 ... but when it comes to Churchill veneration, I'm afraid I think it serves largely to whitewash the British empire, to rebrand it as anti-racist. This is not to say that Churchill was "as bad as Hitler" - he wasn't - but this is precisely why the ranking approach is unhelpful

@CliveBarker1967 ... personally I would much rather that we didn't choose to commemorate the militaristic and imperialist aspects of our past. It depends on how these figures are used to represent and define British identity and history. I'm not really sure what Boudicca means to modern Brits...

@CliveBarker1967 Cross-cultural comparisons of slavery are problematic because it has meant many different things. That's why many historians prefer the term unfree labor for comparative purposes. But I think debates on statues are legit. They're choices about who and what we commemorate...

@omaromalleykhan @CJFDillow Ime (anecdotal from door-knocking), it tends to be boomers who are reasonably well off who are angry at the young. The point about consumerism is just that the prices of things like phones, clothes, computers etc are more visible than house prices bc we buy them regularly

@omaromalleykhan @CJFDillow Also these generations saw social mobility, so there are many like my dad who were born into working class families and ended up middle class. It's difficult for them to accept the idea that they're privileged, bc they still identify to some extent with having been working class

@omaromalleykhan @CJFDillow But in all cases, the truth of what happened to their generation is very hard to accept because it undermines their entire conception of themselves, and of course they have memories of genuinely difficult times that loom larger because they were difficult

@omaromalleykhan @CJFDillow Did a lot of door-knocking in Worthing, v boomery town on the south coast, in 2019. This narrative is very deeply entrenched (even among people who admit they bought their council house at a discount!) In some it provokes anger, in others just skepticism to temper the sympathy

@omaromalleykhan @CJFDillow And, consumer products in general are much cheaper these days. So it's easy to fall for a "never had it so good" interpretation by focusing on those trivial things, rather than housing etc

@omaromalleykhan @CJFDillow My dad's a pretty calm and easy-going guy. The other big difference, in terms of memory, is greater range of consumer products available now
